{{short description|Square in Warsaw}} [[Image:Plac Trzech Krzyży w Warszawie 2019a.jpg|thumb|400px|The Square, looking north toward [[New World Street]]]] [[File:Alexander Church Warsaw.jpg|thumb|250px|[[St. Alexander's Church, Warsaw|St. Alexander's Church]] ca. 1900]]
'''Three Crosses Square''' ({{lang-pl|Plac Trzech Krzyży}}, {{IPAc-pl|'|p|l|a|c|-|'|t|sz|e|ch|-|'|k|sz|y|ż|y}}, also "Square of Three Crosses", "Three Cross Square", and '''"Triple Cross Square"'''<ref>Some have mistakenly objected to applying the English expression "triple cross" to this Warsaw square, claiming that "triple cross" is specifically a synonym for the "[[Papal cross|Papal Cross]]", a staff with three horizontal bars near the top. In reality, "triple cross" simply means "three crosses", as illustrated in the following advertisement for a "triple cross square money clip": [http://www.montanasilversmiths.com/triple-cross-square-money-clip.html]. Similarly, the term "[[Triple Crown (disambiguation)|Triple Crown]]" is often used to describe the winning of the three most important events in a given field; [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|originating in mid-19th century England in the sport of horse racing]], it has since spread to other competitive endeavors.</ref>) is an important square in the [[Śródmieście, Warsaw|central district]] of [[Warsaw]], Poland. It lies on that city's [[Royal Route, Warsaw|Royal Route]] and links [[Nowy Świat Street|Nowy Świat]] (New World) Street, to the north, with [[Ujazdów Avenue]] to the south.
Much of the square's area is devoted to a major thoroughfare.
==History== Until the 18th century, the area now occupied by the square was little more than sparsely-populated open terrain south of the then-city limits of [[Warsaw]].
During the reign of [[Monarchs of Poland|King]] [[Augustus II of Poland|Augustus II the Strong]], between 1724 and 1731, a "road to [[Calvary]]" ([[Stations of the Cross]]) was created, with the first station being located near the present square, and the last station next to [[Ujazdów Castle]] to the south. The first station featured two golden crosses.
In 1752 [[Marszałek#Types|Grand Marshal of the Crown]] [[Franciszek Bieliński]] erected a statue nearby of St. [[John of Nepomuk]], also holding a cross. On account of the three crosses, the populace took to calling the area "''Rozdroże złotych krzyży''"—"the Crossroads of the Golden Crosses".
In the Square stands the [[neoclassicism|neoclassist]] [[St. Alexander's Church, Warsaw|St. Alexander's Church]], designed 1818–25 by the Polish architect [[Chrystian Piotr Aigner]].<ref>"Aigner, Chrystian Piotr," ''[[Encyklopedia Polski]]'', p. 12.</ref><ref>"Aigner, Chrystian Piotr," ''[[Encyklopedia Powszechna PWN]]'' (PWN Universal Encyclopedia), volume 1, p. 32.</ref> Originally the [[Town square|square]] itself also bore the name of [[Alexander I of Russia|Saint Alexander]].
The square takes its present name from three [[Christian cross|cross]]es: one atop St. Alexander's Church, and two atop [[column]]s several dozen meters away, facing the church's entrance.
Contrary to common belief, there are more than three crosses in the square. Apart from the three mentioned above, there are two atop the northern and southern façades of the church, as well as one in front of the Institute for the Deaf (which was erected in 1827 and initially run by the [[Catholic Church]]).
During the 1944 [[Warsaw Uprising]], the square and most of the surrounding buildings were destroyed or deliberately demolished by the Germans. After 1945 the Institute for the Deaf was rebuilt, and the church was rebuilt to its pre-19th-century appearance.
The square now hosts exclusive retail stores — [[Hugo Boss]], [[Burberry]], [[Church's]], [[Ermenegildo Zegna]], [[Max Mara]], Coccinelle, W. Kruk, [[JM Weston]], Franscesco Biasa, [[Escada]], MAX & Co., [[Lacoste]], [[Emporio Armani]] and [[Kenzo (brand)|Kenzo]].
Adjacent to the square is the [[Warsaw Stock Exchange]], an [[HSBC|HSBC Premiere]] office, and a [[Sheraton Hotels and Resorts|Sheraton Hotel]].
